definitions: combine various elements or components into a coherent unified whole
produce a substance artificially through chemical or biological processes
examples: The research team synthesized findings from multiple studies comprehensively
Students must synthesize information from different sources effectively
Scientists synthesized the new compound in their laboratory yesterday
The pharmaceutical company synthesizes insulin for diabetic patients regularly

definitions: inject liquid into something using a syringe medical device
clean or flush something using a syringe to spray liquid
examples: The nurse carefully syringed medication into the patient's arm
The veterinarian syringed the vaccine into the animal quickly
The dentist syringed water to clean the patient's mouth
She syringed the wound with saline solution very gently

definitions: postpone consideration or discussion of a matter until later
present information or data in a systematic tabular format
examples: The committee tabled the motion until next month's meeting
Congress decided to table the controversial bill indefinitely yesterday
The researcher tabled all experimental results in the appendix
Please table your findings in an organized spreadsheet format

definitions: prohibit or restrict something as socially or culturally unacceptable
examples: Many cultures taboo certain foods during religious observances completely
The society tabooed discussion of mental health issues historically

definitions: fasten or attach something using small sharp nails or pins
change a sailing vessel's direction by turning through the wind
add something as an extra item or afterthought to existing content
examples: She tacked the poster to the bulletin board carefully
Workers tacked the carpet edges down along the walls
The sailors tacked repeatedly to reach their destination harbor
We need to tack against the prevailing wind now
They tacked an amendment onto the original bill hastily
The editor tacked a footnote to the article yesterday

definitions: make determined effort to deal with a difficult problem or task
stop or bring down an opponent by physical force in sports
use fishing tackle equipment to catch fish in water
examples: The team tackled the complex project with great enthusiasm
We must tackle climate change through immediate decisive action
The defender tackled the running back near the goal line
The rugby player tackled his opponent around the waist
They tackled for bass in the lake all morning
He tackled the stream using his new fishing rod

definitions: attach a label or marker to something for identification purposes
touch another player in a children's game of chase
mark or identify something electronically using digital tags or markers
examples: Please tag all items with their prices before opening
Scientists tagged the migrating birds for tracking their movements
The child tagged her friend and ran away laughing
You're it when I tag you in this game
Users can tag photos with location data on social media
The system automatically tags suspicious transactions for review later

definitions: follow someone closely and secretly for surveillance or observation purposes
remove the tail from an animal or object during preparation
examples: The detective tailed the suspect through downtown streets carefully
Private investigators often tail people for divorce cases professionally
The chef tailed the shrimp before cooking them tonight
Workers tail the logs before processing them into lumber

definitions: drive dangerously close behind another vehicle on the road
hold a social gathering in a parking area before a sports event
examples: The aggressive driver tailgated me for several miles dangerously
Please don't tailgate other vehicles on the highway ever
Fans tailgated in the stadium parking lot before kickoff
We plan to tailgate before the football game tomorrow

definitions: alter or adjust clothing to fit a particular person's measurements
customize or adapt something to meet specific needs or requirements
examples: The seamstress tailored his suit for the wedding perfectly
She tailors designer dresses for celebrity clients exclusively
We must tailor our approach to each client's needs
The company tailored its services for small businesses specifically

definitions: contaminate or pollute something with a harmful or undesirable substance
damage or spoil the quality or reputation of something negatively
examples: Industrial waste tainted the river water for miles downstream
The bacteria tainted the entire batch of food products
The scandal tainted his reputation in the business community
Corruption has tainted the organization's public image severely

definitions: grasp something with hands and carry it to another location
require a particular amount of time, effort, or resources
accept or receive something that is offered or available
capture or seize control of a place or position forcefully
examples: Please take these books to the library this afternoon
She took her umbrella when leaving the house today
The project will take six months to complete properly
Learning a language takes dedication and consistent daily practice
He decided to take the job offer from Microsoft
Students must take three electives to graduate this year
The army took the city after a lengthy siege
The company took control of its smaller competitor yesterday

definitions: engage in spoken conversation or communication with other people
discuss or speak about a particular topic or subject matter
persuade or influence someone through verbal communication and reasoning
examples: The friends talked for hours at the coffee shop
Children learn to talk around their second birthday typically
Let's talk business over lunch at the restaurant tomorrow
The professor talked about quantum physics during yesterday's lecture
She talked him into joining the volunteer program eventually
The lawyer talked the jury into acquitting his client

definitions: count and record numbers or amounts in a systematic way
correspond or agree with another set of figures or facts
examples: The election officials tallied votes throughout the night carefully
Accountants tally expenses at the end of each month
These figures don't tally with last year's financial report
Her story tallies perfectly with the witness's account yesterday

definitions: domesticate a wild animal through training and gentle handling
make something less powerful, extreme, or difficult to control
examples: Ancient humans first tamed wolves thousands of years ago
The trainer tamed the wild horse over several patient months
Engineers worked to tame the river's destructive flooding patterns
The new policies tamed inflation within just six months

definitions: interfere with something improperly, illegally, or without authorization
examples: Someone tampered with the evidence before the trial began
Never tamper with electrical equipment without proper training first

definitions: make or become brown through exposure to sun or heat
convert animal hide into leather through chemical treatment process
examples: She tanned quickly during her beach vacation last summer
The sun tanned his face after working outside daily
The factory tans thousands of hides every month efficiently
Traditional methods tan leather using natural tree bark extracts

definitions: twist together into a confused mass of threads or strands
involve someone in a conflict or complicated situation
examples: Her long hair tangled in the strong wind yesterday
The fishing lines tangled when we weren't paying attention
Don't tangle with dangerous people in that neighborhood
The company tangled itself in legal disputes for years

definitions: perform the tango dance with rhythmic and passionate movements
engage in conflict or confrontation with another party
examples: The couple tangoed beautifully at the dance competition yesterday
She learned to tango during her visit to Argentina
The two companies have tangoed over market share for years
Politicians often tango with lobbyists over controversial legislation matters

definitions: fail completely or perform very badly in a dramatic way
store liquid or gas in a large container or tank
examples: The movie tanked at the box office last weekend
Their stock price tanked after the earnings report yesterday
The facility tanks millions of gallons of water annually
We need to tank more fuel before the long journey

definitions: strike something lightly with a quick gentle blow or touch
access or make use of a resource or supply
secretly monitor telephone or electronic communications
examples: She tapped him on the shoulder to get attention
The woodpecker tapped rhythmically against the old tree trunk
The company tapped into new markets in Asia successfully
Scientists tapped underground water sources during the severe drought
Intelligence agencies tapped the suspect's phone for months illegally
Hackers tapped into the company's private communication network yesterday

definitions: record sound or video on magnetic tape or digital media
fasten or bind something using adhesive tape material
examples: The journalist taped the entire interview for her article
Musicians taped their new album in a professional studio
Please tape the box securely before shipping it tomorrow
The nurse taped the bandage firmly to his injured arm

definitions: become gradually narrower toward one end in shape or form
gradually decrease in amount, intensity, or degree over time
examples: The candle tapers elegantly toward its top end naturally
The road tapers as it approaches the mountain pass
Medicine dosage should taper gradually to avoid withdrawal symptoms
Their enthusiasm tapered after the initial excitement wore off

definitions: cover or coat a surface with thick black sticky substance
examples: Workers tarred the new road surface yesterday before opening
Sailors traditionally tarred ship ropes to protect them from water

definitions: aim or direct something at a specific target or goal
select someone or something as an object of attention or attack
examples: The archer targeted the bullseye with perfect concentration yesterday
Marketing campaigns target specific demographic groups for maximum effectiveness
Criminals often target elderly people for financial scams unfortunately
The new policy targets tax evaders with severe penalties

definitions: impose a tax on imported or exported goods for trade regulation
examples: The government tariffed imported steel to protect domestic producers
Countries often tariff luxury goods at much higher rates

definitions: lose luster or become dull and discolored through oxidation
damage or destroy the good reputation or image of something
examples: Silver jewelry tarnishes quickly without proper care and storage
The copper statue tarnished after years of weather exposure
The scandal tarnished the politician's previously spotless reputation permanently
False accusations can tarnish an innocent person's good name

definitions: assign a piece of work or duty to someone to complete
examples: The manager tasked her team with completing the project
Teachers task students with homework assignments every single day

definitions: perceive or experience the flavor of something through the mouth
experience or have a brief trial of something
have a particular flavor when eaten or drunk
examples: The chef tasted the soup before serving it tonight
Children often refuse to taste new foods at first
She tasted success with her first published novel recently
The team tasted defeat for the first time yesterday
This wine tastes fruity with hints of oak and vanilla
The milk tastes sour because it has gone bad

definitions: mark skin permanently with decorative designs using ink and needles
examples: The artist tattooed an intricate dragon on his customer's back
Many cultures have tattooed their members for thousands of years

definitions: provoke or challenge someone with insulting or mocking remarks deliberately
examples: Bullies taunted the smaller children during recess every day
The crowd taunted the opposing team throughout the entire game

definitions: impose a compulsory financial charge or levy on income or goods
make heavy demands on someone's physical or mental resources
examples: The government taxes income at different rates progressively nationwide
States tax retail sales to generate revenue for public services
The long hike really taxed our endurance and stamina significantly
Complex calculations tax even the most powerful computer systems

definitions: move slowly on the ground before takeoff or after landing
examples: The plane taxied to the runway for immediate departure
Aircraft must taxi carefully in foggy conditions at airports

definitions: impart knowledge or skill to someone through instruction or example
cause someone to learn or understand something through experience
examples: She teaches mathematics at the local high school daily
Parents teach their children important values throughout their childhood
Life teaches us lessons we never forget completely ever
That experience taught him to be more careful always

definitions: work together as a group to achieve a common goal
pair or join with someone as partners for an activity
examples: The departments teamed to complete the project on schedule
Scientists from different countries teamed on groundbreaking research together
She teamed with her sister to start a business
The companies teamed up for the marketing campaign successfully

definitions: pull apart or rip something into pieces by force
move very quickly in a reckless or excited manner
produce tears from eyes due to emotion or irritation
examples: The dog tore the newspaper into tiny pieces yesterday
Strong winds can tear roofs off houses during hurricanes
The children tore through the house excitedly after school
The motorcycle tore down the highway at dangerous speeds
Onions make your eyes tear when cutting them up
She couldn't help tearing up during the emotional movie

definitions: make fun of or mock someone in a playful way
gently pull or comb something apart to separate fibers
sexually excite or provoke someone without intending to satisfy
examples: His friends constantly tease him about his new haircut
Siblings often tease each other during family gatherings naturally
The hairstylist teased her hair to create more volume
Carefully tease the wool fibers before spinning them together
She enjoyed teasing her admirers at the party last night
The dancer teased the audience with suggestive movements throughout

definitions: place a golf ball on a small peg for the first stroke
examples: The golfer carefully teed up before his opening drive
Players must tee their ball within the designated area

definitions: move or balance unsteadily as if about to fall
be in an unstable situation close to failure or collapse
examples: The toddler teetered on unsteady legs across the room
The stack of books teetered dangerously on the desk edge
The company teetered on the brink of bankruptcy last year
Their relationship has teetered between love and hate constantly

definitions: transmit or broadcast a program or event on television
examples: The network telecast the championship game to millions worldwide
They will telecast the ceremony live tomorrow evening nationally

definitions: send a message using telegraph communication system historically
reveal one's intentions unintentionally through obvious signs or actions
examples: People telegraphed urgent messages across continents before telephones existed
The operator telegraphed the news to distant cities immediately
His nervous behavior telegraphed his guilt to everyone present
The boxer telegraphed his punches making them easy to block

definitions: communicate with someone using a telephone to make a call
examples: Please telephone the office if you'll be late today
She telephoned her mother every Sunday without fail ever

definitions: transport someone or something instantly from one location to another theoretically
examples: In science fiction stories characters often teleport between planets
The magician claimed he could teleport objects across the stage

definitions: compress or cause to slide together in overlapping sections
observe distant objects using an optical telescope instrument
examples: The car's sections telescoped together during the crash impact
The collapsible antenna telescopes into a compact size easily
Astronomers telescope distant galaxies to study their formation patterns
We telescoped the moon's surface during the eclipse yesterday

definitions: broadcast an event or program on television for public viewing
examples: Major networks televise important sporting events live every weekend
The station will televise the presidential debate tomorrow night

definitions: communicate information or a story to someone through speech
distinguish or recognize the difference between things
order or instruct someone to do something with authority
examples: She told her children bedtime stories every single night
Please tell me what happened at the meeting yesterday
Can you tell the difference between these two wines?
It's hard to tell genuine pearls from fake ones
The teacher told students to complete their homework tonight
My boss told me to finish the report immediately

definitions: moderate or reduce the intensity or extremeness of something
strengthen metal through controlled heating and cooling processes
examples: She tempered her criticism with words of encouragement carefully
Experience has tempered his youthful enthusiasm over the years
The blacksmith tempered the steel blade in cold water
Properly tempered glass resists breaking under stress much better

definitions: entice or try to persuade someone to do something wrong
attract someone strongly to want or have something
examples: The devil tempted him with promises of unlimited power
Don't tempt children with candy before dinner time please
The delicious aroma tempted customers into the bakery immediately
Low prices tempt shoppers to buy more than necessary

definitions: occupy a building or land as a tenant paying rent
examples: They have tenanted the apartment for over five years
The company tenants several floors in the downtown building

definitions: care for or look after someone or something regularly
be likely or inclined to behave in a particular way
examples: Nurses tend patients with dedication and professional medical care
Farmers tend their crops throughout the entire growing season
Children tend to imitate their parents' behavior patterns naturally
Prices tend to rise during periods of high demand
